author: sharkhuh
content: For step (3), what is the expected turn around for "all" clients to be able to respond/react to the TTD decision? O(hours)? O(days)? Have the teams tried executing something like this in the past

author: potuz
content: For clients that have flags allowing them to override TTD, there's no need in theory to release binaries with these hardcoded. Unfortunately both the consensus spec and EIP-3675 Explicitly require the binary distribution.

author: m.kalinin
content: A requirement on having TTD parameter in binary distributions still allows for having a CLI flag for the override but doesn't make the flag mandatory. The decision of not mandating the flags was made because it doesn't buy us much time should the override happen, while it introduces a new step into deployment process which can't be as reliable as usual process of upgrading clients.

author: potuz
content: I understand, but the irony now is that the spec mandates for binary releases when they won't be necessary as every client (consensus at least) does have the flags

author: m.kalinin
content: I think it's necessary to have them in binary distributions as it would require taking these parameter into account when starting clients. In this respect flag does look like a short term solution

author: potuz
content: I truly think that this is another instance where the spec is overly specific. What matters is that the beacon node has this parameter specified, I think hardcoding or flags are implementation details and neither should be specified.

author: m.kalinin
content: We already have configuration files that are included into binaries. What spec says (in EIP-3675) is that there is a new set of parameters that should also become a part of this configuration -- there is a MUST word in this statement, probably this MUST is confusing. Consensus specs doesn't have any specific statements about new parameters

author: potuz
content: Ah ok, soIf it's not mandatory to have the hardcoded then there's no reason to release quickly after TTD is decided, regarding the original question by <@416765460344864768>

author: m.kalinin
content:
I see two different cases for changing the TTD value:
1. Setting a real TTD value that is gonna be a fork trigger
2. Overriding TTD value in case of emergency

I think for the first case release should be out and users should upgrade their nodes. For the second we may have CLI flags to enable override, but releases with this value should be out as soon as it's possible to cut a release -- so, new comers who just download clients and launch nodes will use the right value

author: jgm
content:
Allowing withdrawal keys to initiate an exit not only makes the protocol more complicated, but changes the understanding of the difference between withdrawal and validating keys that has been around since genesis.

Is there a specific requirement for this functionality that is significant enough to require this additional work?

author: arwer13
content:
<@144468805697929216> 
Staking pools have to rely on trust in validators to do voluntary exit on demand. Otherwise, not able to fulfil users requests to withdraw their funds
This is the most specific requirement I'm aware of.

In general, I would say, this incapability being around since genesis is more of a bug, thus the earlier it's fixed the better
In theory something somewhere might break due to the change of the assumption. Thus the change must be approached carefully
For me it seems to be lesser evil, than the lasting situation when the owner of the funds is not able to fully control it

author: jgm
content:
This was something that was discussed at the time, though, and the separation of keys was understood.  As such, labelling it as a bug seems inaccurate.

If a user of a staking service wishes to be able to control the exit of their validator they can request a pre-signed exit transaction.  Again, this was discussed at the time and agreed upon as a suitable way of allowing this functionality.

As for the owner of the funds not being able to fully control them, that remains the case because a validator could slash their funds.
